items.title: The underlying database pointer (sqlite3*) is not exposed.
items.body:
On MacOS, the default sqlite3 is not compiled with load-extensions enabled. This means you cannot load virtual table extensions without recompilation of the sqlite3 library. However, if an extension is compiled with the flag -DSQLITE_CORE, then the extension can still be manually loaded by calling the C-entry point to the extension using the c_types interface.

This requires access to the underlying sqlite3* pointer (handle).

Thus, this is a request to expose the sqlite3* database handle to python.

items.title: [Suggestion] Object passed as parameters
items.body:
#### Example
```python3
class C(object):
    def __init__(self, field0, field1):
        self.field0 = field0
        self.field1 = field1

obj = C("foo", "bar")
cursor.execute('''SELECT field1 FROM table WHERE field1=:field1''', obj)
```

When you try to do this a `ValueError` is thrown:
```ValueError: parameters are of unsupported type```

#### Proposal
We could use the `__dict__` field of the object internally, instead of having the user to manually pass it as a parameter.

##### Disclaimer
I don't know this library that much and maybe something like this has already been discussed or implemented, in which case I'm sorry I could not find any information about it.

items.title: type_name is missing in .description cursor attribute
items.body:
Running into issues querying column data types from an sqlite DB using Python. Looks like the sqlite3 library is missing a feature from the Python DB API.

_"The sqlite3 module was written by Gerhard Häring. It provides a SQL interface compliant with the DB-API 2.0 specification described by PEP 249."_

**[sqlite3](https://docs.python.org/2/library/sqlite3.html)**
**.description** "This read-only attribute provides the column names of the last query. To remain compatible with the Python DB API, it returns a 7-tuple for each column where the last six items of each tuple are None."

**[DB-API 2.0](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0249/)**
**.description** "The first two items ( name and type_code ) are mandatory, the other five are optional and are set to None if no meaningful values can be provided."

items.title: Why don't DDL statements open a transaction?
items.body:
796b3afe38cfdac5d7d5ec260826b0a596554631 "introduces" a special case for DDL statements: unlike other statements, they won't open a transaction implicitly when autocommit is off.

("introduces" because it actually adjusts changes from the previous commit...)

The most convenient way to start a database transaction with Python DB-API modules is to turn autocommit off. This commit makes it necessary to special case SQLite by using a BEGIN statement instead of turning autocommit off.

Django currently does this for other reasons (to work around #24, which has been fixed and should make it into Python 3.6). See https://github.com/django/django/blob/271581df606b307d89c141e8b1a50ace763bea81/django/db/backends/base/base.py#L375-L404

I'd love to remove this hack in the long term, but if pysqlite / sqlite3 don't open a transaction consistently when autocommit is off, we'll have to keep it.

In my opinion the least surprising behavior is:
- when autocommit is off (default required by the DB-API) : begin a transaction implicitly if no transaction is in progress, never commit implicitly
- when autocommit is on (default in Django) : never begin a transaction implicitly, never commit implicitly (the latter was #24)

I understand that any documented behavior can be worked around, but it would be so nice if we could keep things simple...

items.title: cursor.description returns non-pep249 complaint value '()'
items.body:
Per [pep 249](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0249/#description), cursor.description is to be a sequence of 7-item tuples describing the columns in a result set.    If the operation does not return rows, it is required to be None:

> This attribute will be None for operations that do not return rows or if the cursor has not had an operation invoked via the .execute*() method yet. 

Per the test case below, a simple "DELETE" SQL statement is returning an empty tuple, rather than None:

```
from pysqlite2 import dbapi2

print dbapi2.version_info

conn = dbapi2.connect(":memory:")
cursor = conn.cursor()

cursor.execute("""
    CREATE TABLE plain_pk (
    id INTEGER NOT NULL,
    data VARCHAR(50),
    PRIMARY KEY (id)
)
""")

cursor.executemany("""
    INSERT INTO plain_pk (id, data) VALUES (?, ?)
""", ((1, 'd1'), (2, 'd2'), (3, 'd3')))

cursor.execute("""
    DELETE FROM plain_pk WHERE plain_pk.id = ?
""", (2,))

assert cursor.description is None, cursor.description


```

output:

```
(2, 8, 2)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 24, in <module>
    assert cursor.description is None, cursor.description
AssertionError: ()

```

this is a behavioral regression which breaks downstream projects such as SQLAlchemy.

items.title: present a file-like interface to blobs
items.body: http://www.sqlite.org/c3ref/blob_open.html and http://www.sqlite.org/c3ref/blob_write.html allow users to incrementally write large objects, which can (at least in principle) allow for smaller memory footprint when processing large blob storage requests.  Given that sqlite supports 64-bit blobs, i.e. larger than would fit in memory, this is necessary to be able to access all of its functionality.

items.title: multiple cursors
items.body:
In https://github.com/web2py/pydal we are facing an issue that can be described by the example below

```
import sqlite3
conn = sqlite3.connect(':memory:')

c1 = conn.cursor()
c2 = conn.cursor()

# Create table
c1.execute('''CREATE TABLE t0
             (qty real)''')
c1.execute('''CREATE TABLE t1
             (qty real)''')

for n in xrange(1, 100, 1):
    c1.execute("INSERT INTO t0 VALUES (%s)" % n)

# Save (commit) the changes
conn.commit()
c1.execute("select * from t0")

ctr=0
while True:
    # Get the next row in the cursor
    row = c1.fetchone()
    if row == None: break

    c2.execute("INSERT INTO t1 VALUES (999)")
    conn.commit()
    ctr += 1

print ctr
conn.close()
```

On python2.6, it prints 99, on all other versions return 101.
By committing out the `conn.commit()` in the loop, the problem disappear. 
Is it the correct behavior?

items.title: Compiling woes
items.body:
Hi, first of all thanks for pysqlite, it's a really neat project.

I posted to the python-sqlite mailing list, but thought I'd open an issue here. Feel free to close if you think I'm barking up the wrong tree.

Basically I'm trying to build pysqlite against my own checkout of SQLite. Specifically I wanted to compile libsqlite with the json1 extension baked in. So, I created an amalgamation and cat'd the json1.c source to the end of the sqlite3.c file per the [official instructions](https://www.sqlite.org/draft/json1.html). I was able to verify that the newly generated libs contained the json functions:

``` console
$ strings libsqlite3.so | grep "json_init"
sqlite3_json_init
sqlite3_json_init
```

What I hoped to do was then clone pysqlite and compile it against my new libsqlite3. I tried modifying setup.cfg, adding lines specifying my `library_dirs` and `include_dirs`, but this did not seem to have any effect. Similarly I modified the code itself in `setup.py` to explicitly set the `include_dirs` and `library_dirs`. Here is the last line of output from setup.py build, leading me to believe my special sqlite should be being used:

```
gcc -pthread -shared -Wl,-O1,--sort-common,--as-needed,-z,relro \
    build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/src/module.o build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/src/connection.o \
    build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/src/cursor.o build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/src/cache.o \
    build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/src/microprotocols.o build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/src/prepare_protocol.o \
    build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/src/statement.o build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/src/util.o \
    build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/src/row.o \
    -L/home/charles/bin/sqlite/lib \
    -L/usr/lib \
    -lpython2.7 \
    -lsqlite3 \
    -o build/lib.linux-x86_64-2.7/pysqlite2/_sqlite.so
```

When testing, I made sure to use the pysqlite in the build/ directory and verified this by ensuring there were no other pysqlite2's on the sys.path.

When I attempt to use a json() function from within my newly-minted pysqlite, I get:

``` ipython
In [1]: from pysqlite2 import dbapi2 as S

In [2]: conn = S.connect(':memory:')

In [3]: conn.cursor().execute('select json(?)', (1,))
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
OperationalError                          Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-3-d113b04b23d3> in <module>()
----> 1 conn.cursor().execute('select json(?)', (1,))

OperationalError: no such function: json
```

I manually compiled the `json1.c` extension, and when I try to load it, I see a missing symbol. This leads me to believe that pysqlite was _not_ compiled against the new sqlite libs:

``` ipython
In [4]: conn.enable_load_extension(True)

In [5]: conn.load_extension('../../../json1')
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
OperationalError                          Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-5-eac92709196f> in <module>()
----> 1 conn.load_extension('../../../json1')

OperationalError: ../../../json1.so: undefined symbol: sqlite3_vsnprintf
```

But note that that function is present in my shared (and static) libraries:

``` console
$ strings libsqlite3.so | grep vsnprintf
sqlite3_vsnprintf
sqlite3_vsnprintf
```

---

Is the problem that my pysqlite is still dynamically linking against the system libsqlite, which does not have the json stuff? Is there a way to force it to always use my custom libsqlite? Am I doing this totally wrong?

Oh, and just wondering, I noticed that `setup.cfg` no longer includes lines for `include_dirs` and `library_dirs` -- how should one go about specifying these?

items.title: Get rid of statement parsing
items.body:
pysqlite uses statement parsing to determine if it should auto-start a transaction. Auto-starting transactions is needed for DB-API 2.0 compatibiltiy.

A much better solution is to use sqlite3_stmt_readonly() to determine if a transaction should be started or not.

items.title: setup.py egg_info fails when sphinx isn't present
items.body:
Hi, I ran into a problem with pysqlite when testing some co-installability stuff with openstack's dependencies.

The issue is that python setup.py egg_info, which pip uses to determine what the install_requires for a package is, fails if sphinx isn't installed. Since you don't use setuptools pip is having to inject some nasty glue to get setuptools commands, but thats by-the-by :)

It looks to me like you want to build docs at sdist/install time- which is totally fine :). However, egg_info is neither sdist nor installation, and is needed to let pip get far enough along to actually try sdist/install.

There are a couple of patterns here, I don't know which is most appropriate for pysqlite, but here they are:
- disable the docs if the deps are not present
- use setuptools (its recommended everywhere now, I know of no reason not to use it), and export your dependencies via setup_requires

I suggest the latter one, since you refer folk to use easy-install to install sphinx; setuptools w/setup_requires will install sphinx just-in-time and then you can sanely use it.

items.title: Python3 is not supported
items.body:
From looking at the code, it's pretty clear that this package does not support Python3. For example, even your setup script still uses print statements [instead of functions](https://docs.python.org/3.0/whatsnew/3.0.html#print-is-a-function) (e.g. [here](https://github.com/ghaering/pysqlite/blob/master/setup.py#L85)) and [raises exceptions with comma separated arguments](https://github.com/ghaering/pysqlite/blob/master/cross_bdist_wininst.py#L86) [which is no longer supported](http://docs.pythonsprints.com/python3_porting/py-porting.html#exceptions).

I don't know if you have plans to support Python3. However, in the mean time, could you at least specify "Programming Language :: Python :: 2" in your trove classifiers to make it clear that 3 is _not_ supported?

items.title: Cursor.lastrowid always None when using first line SQL comments
items.body:
**Summary:**
Cursor.lastrowid will always return None when using a SQL comments (-- or /*) in the first line of the statement.

After some debugging, It appears that [detect_statement_type](https://github.com/ghaering/pysqlite/blob/master/src/cursor.c#L41) will return STATEMENT_OTHER when given a statement which contains a SQL comment as the first line. Since the logic in [_pysqlite_query_execute](https://github.com/ghaering/pysqlite/blob/master/src/cursor.c#L750) will only attempt to populate lastrowid when running a single INSERT statement, it is always left as None.

This reproduces on both on both pysqlite2 and sqlite3 baked into Python 2.7.5.

**Steps to Reproduce:**

```
from pysqlite2 import dbapi2 as sqlite3
print sqlite3.version
print sqlite3.sqlite_version

SCHEMA = 'CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS people (first TEXT, last TEXT)'

BAD_SINGLE_LINE_INSERT = '-- This is a comment!\nINSERT INTO people (first, last) VALUES (?, ?)'

BAD_MULTI_LINE_INSERT = """
-- This is a comment
INSERT INTO people (first, last) VALUES (?, ?)
"""

GOOD_SINGLE_LINE_INSERT = 'INSERT INTO people (first, last) VALUES (?, ?)'

def main():
    db = sqlite3.connect(':memory:')
    cursor = db.cursor()
    cursor.execute(SCHEMA)
    cursor.execute(BAD_SINGLE_LINE_INSERT, ('Foo', 'Bar'))
    print cursor.lastrowid
    cursor.execute(BAD_MULTI_LINE_INSERT, ('Foo2', 'Bar2'))
    print cursor.lastrowid
    cursor.execute(GOOD_SINGLE_LINE_INSERT, ('Foo3', 'Bar3'))
    print cursor.lastrowid

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```

**Output:**

```
$python main.py
2.6.3
3.8.7.2
None
None
3

```

**Workaround:**
Minor inconvenience in this case as we can just comment outside of the SQL statements or any position other than the first line.

items.title: race condition bug? Bind error on cursor.execute. Second try with exact same vars works.
items.body:
Hello,

In a program where multiple times cursors are opened, select and other statements are performed and then closed. 
Some of those select statements fail with the following error. This error does not happen, if the exact same line is executed again, with exactly the same variables. 

```
InterfaceError: Error binding parameter 0 - probably unsupported type.
```

So something like this fails occasionally. (Where the dataStr is more than 160 characters long. )

``` python
cursor = conn.cursor()
results = cursor.execute ("SELECT * FROM tableName WHERE Data_One LIKE ? AND is_bla=? AND Data_ola=?;", (dataStr + '%', '1', '8',))
hi = results.fetchone()
cursor.close()
```

And something like this works.

``` python
cursor = conn.cursor()
try:
    results = cursor.execute ("SELECT * FROM tableName WHERE Data_One LIKE ? AND is_bla=? AND Data_ola=?;", (dataStr + '%', '1', '8',))
except:
    results = cursor.execute ("SELECT * FROM tableName WHERE Data_One LIKE ? AND is_bla=? AND Data_ola=?;", (dataStr + '%', '1', '8',))
hi = results.fetchone()
cursor.close()
```

items.title: ``cursor.description`` difference when querying table versus view
items.body:
When querying a table, the cursor description contains the name of the column, even though I've aliased the table in the query.

However, when querying a view, the cursor description contains both the alias and the column name.

Here is an example:

``` python
import sqlite3

conn = sqlite3.connect(':memory:')

cursor = conn.cursor()
cursor.execute('create table people (name);')
cursor.execute('insert into people values (?)', ('charlie',))

cursor.execute('select t1.name from people as t1')
print cursor.description
# (('name', None, None, None, None, None, None),)

cursor.execute('create view people_view as select * from people')
cursor.execute('select t1.name from people_view as t1')
print cursor.description
# (('t1.name', None, None, None, None, None, None),)
```

Output:

```
(('name', None, None, None, None, None, None),)
(('t1.name', None, None, None, None, None, None),)
```

Is this expected behavior?

Also, thank you for the excellent library!

items.title: executescript commits the transaction even if isolation_level = None
items.body:
_From [ikar...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/101505471595569338189/) on May 02, 2013 17:16:47_

The following script should print "My precious data is here.", but it raises an exception instead...
I think pysqlite should not implicitly mess with transactions in "autocommit" mode (when isolation_level = None).

My proposed patch corrects the problem.
### BEGIN

import pysqlite2.dbapi2 as sqlite3
# import sqlite3

con = sqlite3.connect(':memory:')
con.isolation_level = None
cur = con.cursor()

cur.execute('create table test(t text)')
cur.execute('insert into test(t) values(?)', ('My precious data is here.',))
# after the next command, inTransaction will be 1,
# because of the following line in cursor.c, (line 762):
# 
# self->connection->inTransaction =
# !sqlite3_get_autocommit(self->connection->db);
# 

cur.execute('begin')

cur.execute('drop table test')
# Now issue an arbitrary dummy command using executescript.
# executescript implicitly calls pysqlite_connection_commit.
# Since inTransaction == 1, this will actually commit the transaction.

cur.executescript('select 2+3')
# There is no way to roll back.

cur.execute('rollback')

for x in cur.execute('select t from test'):
    print(x[0])

cur.close()
con.close()
### END

**Attachment:** [patch.diff test.py](http://code.google.com/p/pysqlite/issues/detail?id=59)

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysqlite/issues/detail?id=59_

_From [elm...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/111358000878540126601/) on May 06, 2012 12:31:45_

Code:
import pysqlite2.dbapi2 as DB
from decimal import Decimal
import os

dbname = 'test.db3'
value = Decimal('123.456')

def rev_typecast_decimal(d):
    if d is None:
        return None
    return str(d)

DB.register_adapter( Decimal, rev_typecast_decimal )

print DB.version_info

try:
    os.unlink( dbname )
except:
    pass

conn = DB.Connection( dbname )

conn.execute( 'create table test (d decimal)' )
conn.execute( 'insert into test values(?)', (value,))

print list( conn.execute('select \* from test') )
print list( conn.execute('select \* from test where d = ?', (value,) ))
print list( conn.execute('select sum(d) from test group by d having sum(d) = ?', (value,) ))
print list( conn.execute('select sum(d) from test group by d having sum(d) = 123.456' ))

I get:
(2, 6, 3)
[(123.456,)]
[(123.456,)]
[]
[(123.456,)]

While the 3rd select also return [(123.456,)] as it is the same as last one.

Not sure if this is pysqlite2 problem or underlying sqlite3 api, so please let me know if you can replicate and/or need to know anything else.

items.title: [Sugestion] Unify execute() and executescript()
items.body:
_From [piranna](https://code.google.com/u/piranna/) on August 14, 2011 15:33:00_

execute() method (both in cursor and connection) accept as a second parameter a dict or a tuple to use as parameters for the SQL query being executed, but only accept one query at a time, so when you need to exec several queries is ineficient and, as far as i know, insecure in multithreaded applications because if you are not in a transaction one is created automatically for every statement, and another connection would be able to access to the database between two queries-in-a-row (because they are different calls).

On the other hand, executescript() can be able to exec several SQL queries in a row (and AFAIK, the other threads are not able to access to the database until executescript() has finished to exec all its queries), but doesn't accept any parameter for the query so you have to compose it by hand, what it's somewhat insecure and in any case, ugly.

What i proposs is to allow to execute() to support the execution of several queries in a row as executescript() does, and if there's no other technicall difference or performance is not affected, i would deprecate executescript(), having this way only two functions to exec queries, execute() and executemany() (that doesn't have almost anything in common with the others and i don't know if it would be possible or desirable also to unify...).

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysqlite/issues/detail?id=41_

items.title: Extreme inefficiency of pysqlite compared to sqlite and apsw
items.body:
_From [kaushik....@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/109059794947950815445/) on June 14, 2011 20:51:17_

I'm running a somewhat complex SQL query on an sqlite database. The attached script creates an example database and runs my query to illustrate how much more time pysqlite takes to execute the query compared to apsw. Doing the query directly in an sqlite3 shell yeilds the same fast result that apsw returns.

For small databases (say 10 to 100 entries) both libraries yeild similar performance (but pysqlite is consistently slower)

When we get to 1000,2000 and then 4000 the time difference becomes extreme, making pysqlite unusable.

It appears that the execution time for apsw and sqlite directly is linear with the db size, while for pysqlite it is exponential.

I am very puzzled by this difference.

items.title: Text type converter isn't called on empty string, PySQLite returns None
items.body:
_From [oleg.bro...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/102116089267640952931/) on April 15, 2011 14:29:33_

import sqlite3 as sqlite

con = sqlite.connect(":memory:", detect_types=sqlite.PARSE_DECLTYPES)
cur = con.cursor()

cur.execute("""CREATE TABLE test (
    id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT,
    name TEXT)""")

cur.execute('INSERT INTO test VALUES (?,?)', (1, None))
cur.execute('INSERT INTO test VALUES (?,?)', (2, ''))
cur.execute('INSERT INTO test VALUES (?,?)', (3, '42'))

cur.execute('SELECT \* FROM test ORDER BY id')
for rec in cur.fetchall(): print rec

def stop_pysqlite2_converting_strings(s):
    print "--converter-- s:", s
    return s

sqlite.register_converter('TEXT', stop_pysqlite2_converting_strings)

cur.execute('SELECT \* FROM test ORDER BY id')
for rec in cur.fetchall(): print rec

For this program I expected the output to be

(1, None)
(2, u'')
(3, u'42')
--converter-- s: 
--converter-- s: 42
(1, None)
(2, '')
(3, '42')

Instead I got

(1, None)
(2, u'')
(3, u'42')
--converter-- s: 42
(1, None)
(2, None)
(3, '42')

It seems in case of a registered converter PySQLite doesn't call it to convert None or an empty string; instead it just converts them to None.

Is it a bug or a misfeature?

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysqlite/issues/detail?id=34_

items.title: pysqlite requires a newer version of sqlite than indicated by documentation
items.body:
_From [chip...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/105142140781878744392/) on February 15, 2011 11:16:53_

What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Attempt to install pysqlite through easy_install on a machine with sqlite 3.6.10. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? I'd expect it to either notify me that the version is out of date, or (hopefully) build the static module for me.

Instead, I see:

gcc -pthread -fno-strict-aliasing -DNDEBUG -g -fwrapv -O2 -Wall -Wstrict-prototypes -fPIC -DMODULE_NAME="pysqlite2.dbapi2" -DSQLITE_OMIT_LOAD_EXTENSION=1 -I/usr/include/python2.6 -c src/module.c -o build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.6/src/module.o
In file included from src/module.c:27:
src/backup.h:34: error: expected specifier-qualifier-list before ‘sqlite3_backup’
error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1 What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? Tested on an Ubuntu 9.04 build VM with sqlite 3.6.10. Please provide any additional information below. The documentation claims compatibility with sqlite 3.0.8 or newer. At the very least, this should be updated. I don't know what the minimum version truly is (I've tested with 3.6.10, which fails, and 3.6.22, which succeeds). The sqlite3_backup API was added in 3.6.11, though.

Granted, in my case, the server's a bit old now, and I'll likely be updating it, but it was unclear why things were failing initially, requiring a bit of work to find out that it was a version incompatibility and not some generic breakage or Python dev headers problem.

In general, installing this manually and building a static module would be fine, except in this case it's part of a test suite that auto-installs dependencies, so it's a bit harder.

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysqlite/issues/detail?id=32_

items.title: In python 2.5, WHERE name="string" crashes, WHERE name='string' works
items.body:
_From [DjanR...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/109913905378959811966/) on January 31, 2011 16:19:39_

What steps will reproduce the problem? With pysqlite, use a SELECT with a WHERE clause that compares a column with a double quoted string, e.g. WHERE name="John". This causes python 2.5 to crash.

The crash details are:
 AppName: pythonw.exe  AppVer: 0.0.0.0
 ModName: _sqlite.pyd  ModVer: 0.0.0.0
 Offset: 0000b2cc
 All the gory Windows DLL details are available if needed. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The same code works using python 2.5's standard library sqlite3. What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? Just downloaded the latest pysqlite-2.6.0.win32-py2.5.exe on Windows XP SP3. Please provide any additional information below. Note the problem seems related to the syntax:
  WHERE column="string"

crashes, while:
  WHERE column IN ( "string" )

works.

The following code will reproduce the problem:

from pysqlite2 import dbapi2 as sqlite3
# import sqlite3

db = sqlite3.connect( ':memory:' )

db.execute( 'CREATE TABLE Test ( NameId INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,'\
                                'Name   TEXT );' )

db.execute( 'INSERT INTO Test ( Name ) VALUES ( "Mike"  );' )
db.execute( 'INSERT INTO Test ( Name ) VALUES ( "John" );' )
db.execute( 'INSERT INTO Test ( Name ) VALUES ( "Bill" );' )
# Works for sqlite3 and pysqlite

for name in db.execute( "SELECT \* FROM ( SELECT \* FROM Test ) WHERE Name='John';" ):
  print name
# Works for sqlite3 and pysqlite

for name in db.execute( 'SELECT \* FROM ( SELECT \* FROM Test ) WHERE Name IN ( "John" );' ):
  print name
# Works for sqlite3
# Crashes pysqlite

for name in db.execute( 'SELECT \* FROM ( SELECT \* FROM Test ) WHERE Name="John";' ):
  print name

db.close()

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysqlite/issues/detail?id=29_

items.title: Can't compile pysqlite with lastest amalgamation
items.body:
_From [jorge.vargas](https://code.google.com/u/jorge.vargas/) on January 28, 2011 16:22:35_

It seems like the amalgamation file format has changed, making the zipfile code break.

A temporal workaround is to upzip the amalgamation manually.

Using this abstract of the code 

import zipfile
import os
AMALGAMATION_ROOT = 'amalgamation'

def unzip():
    zf = zipfile.ZipFile("tmp.zip")
    print [f.filename for f in zf.infolist()]
    directory = zf.infolist()[0].filename
    files = ["sqlite3.c", "sqlite3.h"] 
    for fn in files:
        print "Extracting", fn
        outf = open(AMALGAMATION_ROOT + os.sep + fn, "wb")
        outf.write(zf.read(fn))
        outf.close()
    zf.close()
    os.unlink("tmp.zip")

unzip()

You will notice the error if it's being run.

(venv)-bash-3.2$ python test_unzip.py 
['sqlite-amalgamation-3070400/', 'sqlite-amalgamation-3070400/shell.c', 'sqlite-amalgamation-3070400/sqlite3.c', 'sqlite-amalgamation-3070400/sqlite3.h', 'sqlite-amalgamation-3070400/sqlite3ext.h']
Extracting sqlite3.c
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test_unzip.py", line 18, in <module>
    unzip()
  File "test_unzip.py", line 13, in unzip
    outf.write(zf.read(fn))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.6/zipfile.py", line 834, in read
    return self.open(name, "r", pwd).read()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.6/zipfile.py", line 857, in open
    zinfo = self.getinfo(name)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.6/zipfile.py", line 824, in getinfo
    'There is no item named %r in the archive' % name)
KeyError: "There is no item named 'sqlite3.c' in the archive"

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysqlite/issues/detail?id=28_

items.title: strange behaour of prepared statements
items.body:
_From [Eir...@gmail.com](https://code.google.com/u/110146931537524045102/) on November 19, 2010 20:39:26_

What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. create new table with 'create table any(id int primary key, a int);'
2. fill table with prepared statement and 1000 values (1,2,3,4,5): 
cur.executemany("insert into any (count, id, a, sec, dev, g0) values (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ? ,? ,?,?)', ((1,2,3,4,5),)*1000)
3. you have no exception with this wrong prepared statement and data, but there will be no data in table.

ah, yes, transactions are not change anything. Inserting correct data with correct prepared statement will be correct.

I don't know if this python-specific and I should push this example to SQLite bugtracker.

Environment: 
_OS:_ FreeBSD 8
_packages:_
- Python26-2.6.6
- Sqlite3-3.7.3
- py26-sqlite3-2.6.6_1

items.title: pysqlite treats SAVEPOINT and RELEASE as DDL (nested transactions don't work)
items.body:
_From [skrulx](https://code.google.com/u/skrulx/) on October 29, 2010 01:11:27_

Nested transactions do not work with pysqlite because the SAVEPOINT and RELEASE statements are not recognized as non-DLL which cause implicit commits to be issued before execution.

Attached is a simple patch that adds "savepoint" and "release" to the list of statements that don't cause an implicit commit.

**Attachment:** [savepoint.patch](http://code.google.com/p/pysqlite/issues/detail?id=24)

_Original issue: http://code.google.com/p/pysqlite/issues/detail?id=24_
